title: Brian Reade: Soundbitten to death by Johnson and Trump’s three-word distractions
text:

IN the run-up to Donald Trump’s inauguration I did a tour of Pennsylvania’s “Rust Belt” to find out why they’d put him in the White House.

The conversations were short affairs. There were no tales of conscience-wrestling, no deep explanation of how Trump had won them over, just brief statements of defiance: “There’s too many immigrants... Hillary’s a liar... he’ll stuff China... we want our jobs back.”

Answers that were variations of three-word soundbites Trump had drummed into their heads at rallies. Short, sharp slogans that spoke to their gut instincts: “Build the wall... lock her up... drain the swamp... Make America Great.”

All sold to them by a practised con man who painted himself as a reg’lar kinda guy despite being a billionaire property magnate who was about as reg’lar as the Sultan of Brunei.

They say that when America sneezes, Britain catches a cold, and so the dreaded three-word disease, which kills all known brain cells, was bound to reach here. We saw the symptoms during the EU referendum with Take Back Control but at this week’s Tory conference there was a full-blown outbreak.

Boris Johnson didn’t bother crafting a proper maiden speech as party leader, outlining a personal vision or original policies. He just rehashed stale jokes and massaged the Tory law ‘n’ order G-spot, but mostly he went for the Trumpian three-word triple-score with constant references to The Surrender Act, Unite The Country and the Get Brexit Done.

Even though many of us watching were thinking No Parliamentary Majority, Lied To Queen and Petrified Of Farage.

Johnson now even refers to himself in three words, The Incredible Hulk, and ignores tough questions by emoting in three-word distractions “let’s think positive”. And the only memorable clip of the week came from an aide’s three-word warning: “No. Disposable. Cups”.

As in America, ­argument and intellect have been sacrificed at the altar of emotion. The language of Shakespeare and Dickens and the oratory of Bevan and Churchill are distant memories.

Debate is the enemy of the people. Why else did Johnson want to close down Parliament?

We’re living in a post-reason world. When the British and American leaders open their mouths we don’t believe a word that leaves them. We know it’s fiction. They know we know it’s fiction. But it doesn’t matter to them. It’s all part of a game which aims to mesmerise the lowest common denominator.

They even have a shared list of shame: grope allegations from young women who were working for them, affairs with busty blondes on the make, racist and sexist comments passed off as ­bar-room banter, serious accusations brazenly dismissed as fake news or the work of foreign colluders.

And their core base loves them even more for it. As Katie Hopkins said of journalist Charlotte Edwardes’ claim that Johnson groped her: “If Boris had squeezed my upper thigh 20 years ago I still wouldn’t have showered. Better to be grabbed by the p***y than have a p***y as Prime Minister.”

No language can educate a mind that polluted. It’s why, like Trump, none of the Johnson scandal sticks. In a three-word world minds quickly move on.

Our only hope is that even the thickest voters see through them and turn their three-word phrases into two.

Ones that begin and end in F.
